ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Increased my French proficiency, learned about cabinets of curiosity and their role in Europe
Understanding of the culture surrounding cabinets of curiosity, how collectors do their work, and of the intellectual history of the Renaissance period.

We learned about curiosity cabinets in the Renaissance and different methods of cataloging items both in the Renaissance and modern times. We got to visit the Beinecke several times, as well as the Cushing brain collection at the medical history library and the Peabody! I also improved my ability to read Old French spellings and grammar.
I learned about a part of French history that was relatively unfamiliar to me before, and I improved my spoken and written French.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths  kind, knowledgeable professor who led the seminar efficiently and effectively 

Weaknesses  little to no clarity on grading/standing throughout term

The field trips were by far the best part of the course! I do wish we had made our own cabinets of curiosity in addition to studying ones we had learned about, I think it would have been cool to put curatorial skills to the test.

Strengths: the combination of field trips and lectures was really good! The field trips were especially really fun and I learned so much from visiting each collection. For our essays, we focused on tracing the history of one particular object or type of object through catalogs of Renaissance curiosity cabinets. The format of getting to choose what object we wanted to focus on and doing this independent research was really fun! Weaknesses: at the beginning of the semester, there was a lot of reading for each class, but Prof Brancher lightened the load later on and the class became very manageable.

The readings were fascinating, and the structure of the course (with its many visits to museums and libraries around New Haven) was brilliant, unlike any other course I've taken at Yale. I genuinely looked forward to this class  it felt like I was going on a little intellectual adventure every Wednesday, whether or not we were in HQ. 

My one gripe: I think it's always tough to have the first assignment receiving any sort of feedback or grade come in the middle of the semester (or even after the halfway mark). We had one presentation and two essays, all (at least in my case) on the same topic, so it felt largely like one project stretched over the final month or two of the fall, taking a few different forms. I didn't receive feedback on my presentation, which would have been nice. But there were clear guidelines for this work, and we were provided with so many interesting documents and sources that it was fun to do, genuinely.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, I would recommend it to someone looking for a relatively low workload class while still practicing/improving their spoken French

Yes! It was a really fun time, and Prof Brancher and TA Louise are absolutely incredible instructors and human beings. The visits to the Beinecke, medical history library, and Peabody were definitely highlights, and the way the class is structured around your own independent research project about an object of your choice is very cool. If you're fluent in French and looking for a non-literature course in the language (as I was), I totally recommend this course.
Yes! It was small and engaging, and the material included some of the most bizarre and surprising stuff I've encountered as an undergrad. (Think kidney stones, plants that look like people...)
